App description:
*NEW UPDATE!* All Jobs + Infinite Overtime now include subtitles and additional language support!   

In a world where robots have replaced all human jobs, step into the "Job Simulator" to learn what it was like 'to job'.    

Players can relive the glory days of work by simulating the ins and outs of being a gourmet chef, an office worker, a convenience store clerk, and more.     

Key Jobbing Features:  
 Throw a stapler at your boss!   
 Learn to 'job' in four not-so historically accurate representations of work-life before society was automated by robots!   
 Use your hands to stack, manipulate, throw, and smash physics objects in an inexplicably satisfying way!   
 Aggressively chug coffee and eat questionable food from the trash!   
 Gain valuable life experience by firing new employees, serving slushy treats, brewing English tea, and ripping apart car engines! 
 Work the never-ending night shift with Infinite Overtime mode!

If this game didn't have it, it would have suffered from being funny only for the first time once.
Each [DAY] job has about 17-19 scripted tasks with railroaded solutions, sure you can throw a stapler at BossBot, but it doesn't change anything later on. No randomness, no consequences, no branching paths, no variation except for the jobs themselves giving you unique and robust tools each.

This is why I absolutely love the Infinite Overtime mode for adding randomness and the ability to [JOB] properly... To the point I've found myself coming back and completing over 1900 tasks, at the time of writing, between all four jobs with [AUTO MECHANIC] being my favourite. I dunno, I just find it quite mesmerising serving 25-50 Bots in a row especially when you get into a flow and each customer is never exactly the same.

That said, especially in contrast with Vacation Simulator, I feel this game is definitely showing its age and long overdue for some sort of update that breaths new life into it. Subtitles are a great start which makes me anxious to see what else is in stock.

I enjoyed those GDC speeches Owlchemy gave and wonder if this game could be updated or retrofitted with features/tools/food items/assets from Vacation Simulator or perhaps re-tool existing jobs into new locations like turning the Convenience store into a Concession stand at a cinema or the Office into a Front Desk/Reception job which use the same tools like the computer and copier for instance.

I was curious to try Job Simulator over Vacation and I'm happy I got to try this old HTC gem on Oculus Quest.

A good game to introduce VR

The game is simulating 4 kinds of jobs, with specific tasks to be completed in each job.
The tasks dont require hard thinking, so the game is a great introduction to VR. You can invite friends to play, and watch what they are doing while having a great laugh. There are several jokes scattered inside the jobs, some are part of the tasks, and some are easter eggs you have to find.
It takes around 30 min to complete all tasks in one job, and around 15 min more to find all easter eggs.

However, the tasks in each job get repetitive, and this might get boring after a while. I found myself finishing tasks just to finish the game without enjoying them as much I did at the start.
If you are looking for a game to laugh at with friends - this is the game to get, but if you are looking for a real puzzle game, this is not a good pick.
It is also slightly overpriced for the experience, in my opinion.

FUN and ENTERTAINING

This game is amazing. I barely get bored from playing, I always find myself playing for hours every time I open the game. I would explain how exactly how it this game is great by talking about CONTENT, and EVERYTHING ELSE.


CONTENT: In the game you can do 4 jobs, Office Worker, Cooking, Supermarket Cashier, and Auto Mechanic. These jobs have one thing in-common, you grab/pull an object to get a job to do from a bot. You do that job until its done, then move on to the next. Even if that doesnt sound like much each job you get is ether something normal like printing a document or make a cup of tea, but you also get robbed or to remove lemons from a car made out of lemons, you never know what is going to happen. You can do so much in each job, I also like throwing stuff around and also seeing what objects do with a action. These jobs however do come to an end, after 20 or 30 assignments to complete the job. However you can just replay the job, but there is a mode called Infinite Overtime (Ill call it IO). In IO you go to work at night and will do it to end of time, there is a assignment counter counting every assignment you can complete. There is still more, after completing all 4 jobs you unlock Mods. First of all no there not community mods, there chips that changes physics of the world. However there are only two mods, one that makes low gravity, and the other makes ever object more bounce. It makes the game more fun and interesting, but I would like it if their would be more mods like 5 or 6.


EVERYTHING ELSE: The games is also great at everything else like graphics, audio, music, bugs, runtime, how it runs, and other. The graphics arent things that wont impress you that much or at all, but it is still good. Audio is also good but not impressive at all, audio is audio. There is barely any music but you may find a radio the plays music in the jobs and it fine. Of course theres bugs, its a VR game so there is some but nothing you will notice at all. The game is short, you can complete by clearing your entire day. The game runs great and clear, so thats good I guess. And the price, the price is fine, no complaints.

Overall this game is really fun and I do recommend this game to anyone who has a VR headset.

I give it 5 Stars

LasagnaWaffleSep 24, 2019 at 10:59 AM
Amazing game, need more to do

Ok, this was an amazing game. the graphics are cartoony, and it has a small human mode you can turn on so smaller kids can still enjoy it. When you start the game, you are a human in the year 2050 where the world is mostly run by job-obsessed robots. You start in a job museum where you get to choose from four different game cartridges, office worker, chef, gas station clerk, and mechanic. The office worker, my favorite, has donuts, coffee, and a computer you can put discs into and play games like flappy bot (flappy bird) and another Zork-style game. You also have a copying machine (try to copy your hand, it's hilarious). As a chef, you have access to a auto-refilling pantry and fridge, along with a radioactive microwave. Your job is to serve customers the food they want. As the mechanic, cars will come in and need repairs or upgrades on their vehicles. You also have access to four radio stations, including the one and only Car Talk radio, station 110.010101. The gas station clerk is like a simulated version of a Walmart worker, where you can fill up slushies, make hot dogs, consume both, and even clean the store. The game also has an infinite overtime mode, where you can do any of the jobs for as long as you want, however, the orders do get repetitive. This was the first game I bought on my quest, and though it was fun to watch others play and play it myself, it did eventually get boring. However, for $20, it was worth it. I'm really hoping they bring the sequel, Vacation Simulator, to the quest soon.
